data.answer: The suffix given is "ı". The suffix "ı" is added directly to the word root "devam". Since there is only one suffix, the order of application is straightforward. The derived word "devamı" rougly translates to "continuation of" in English and is grammatically correct. <Yes>
data.sentence: plüton bize ilk dersini verdi ___ da gelecek

data.answer: First, "liğ" then "imiz" is applied to the root "birlikte". According to Turkish grammar rules, this order of suffixes is allowed and the derived word "birlikteliğimiz" roughly translates to "our togetherness" in English. Hence, the derived word is grammatically incorrect. <Yes>

data.answer: First, "m" then "da" and "ydı" are applied to the root "karşı". According to Turkish grammar rules, this order of suffixes is allowed and the derived word "karşımdaydı" roughly translates to "it was in front of me" in English. Hence, the derived word is grammatically correct. <Yes>

data.answer: First, "lar" then "ı", "ydı" and "k" are applied to the root "sayfa". According to Turkish grammar rules, this order of suffixes is allowed and the derived word "sayfalarıydık" roughly translates to "we were their pages" in English. Hence, the derived word is grammatically correct. <Yes>

data.answer: First, "ler" then "i", "nde", "ki" and "nden" are applied to the root "film". According to Turkish grammar rules, this order of suffixes is allowed and the derived word "filmlerindekinden" roughly translates to "from those that are in their films" in English. Hence, the derived word is grammatically correct. <Yes>

data.answer: First, "a" then "ma", "dık", "lar", "ım" and "sa" are applied to the root "ol". According to Turkish grammar rules, this order of suffixes is allowed and the derived word "olamadıklarımsa" roughly translates to "and the ones that I couldn't become" in English. Hence, the derived word is grammatically correct. <Yes>

data.answer: First, "sal" then "laş", "tır", "ıl", "ma", "dığ" and "ı" are applied to the root "tanrı". According to Turkish grammar rules, this order of suffixes is allowed and the derived word "tanrısallaştırılmadığı" roughly translates to "the fact that it was not made to be god-like". Hence. the derived word is grammatically correct. <Yes>
